docs.title: Sample preparation (carbonate)
docs.text:
• Sample vial: disposable 12 mL borosilicate glass vial (Labco 9RK8)
  • Sample size: 100–200 µg. Tighten cap until septum is slightly depressed in the center.
  • Sequence (16 standards + 50 samples), 96 positions:
    • 8 bypass (last run Carrara Z)
    • Carrara Z × 3, Fletton clay
    • 8 bypass (6 last run Carrara Z, 2 last run Fletton clay)
    • (10 samples, Carrara Z × 2) × 4, 10 samples, Fletton clay, Carrara Z × 3
    • 8 dummies for acid drop
    • 6 acid reservoirs

docs.title: Procedures
docs.text:
1. Check data (esp. last one) and acid usage
  2. Check flow rate (>80 mL/min) on GasBench (2) to decide measure/re-flush the next batch
  3. Check acid pump (esp. Monday)
    1. Forward
    2. manually click button on acid pump multiple times: should be <4s?? per drop
    3. wipe off acid
    4. consider changing Acid Pump–Calibrate...
  4. Put on dummies/standards/samples
  5. Needle maintenance
    1. magnifier
      • curve is original/smooth
      • hole is clear
    2. use little drill to clean: poke in <1 mm, no need to be too invasive unless last batch:
      • first two peaks are smaller than latter peaks
      • peaks do not gradually decrease one by one
    3. put capillaries behind the arm of auto-sampler and put back needles
  6. Aquisation: choose and edit .seq file
    • usually use Carbonate Acid Measure 50 Extra8.seq (with Acid Drop & Measure.met), if more acid drops are needed for some samples with less TIC, use Carbonate Acid Measure 50 Extra8 diff drops.seq and change method into, for instance, Acid Drop & Measure 12 drops.met for these samples
    • input Identifier 1 for samples, Identifier 2 (weight) for standards
    • Options: update date in the Folder Name and Export File Name
    • Save
  7. Check: Ref CO2 On/Off (esp. Monday)
  8. Start
  9. Check first bypass: peaks should gradually decrease one by one

docs.title: Replace filament (#1027920)
docs.text:
1. turn off: source, needle valve (clockwise), main & secondary pumps (on the panel, hear the turbo pump down)
    • Inlet pump: for dual inlet
  2. dismantle ion source
    1. open door by loosen 2 socket screws
    2. unplug 3 cables without damaging the PCB
    3. loose 4 screws
    4. remove 3 screws
    5. press source when loosening the 4th screw to prevent it popping out
  3. replace filament
    1. gloves on
    2. check with multimeter
    3. take off 4 screws (hold with tweezers to protect ceramics)
    4. half tighten 2 screws, push filament up left, fully tighten 2 screws
    5. insert two leads (+/−) into the slots
    6. press and check the metal connections
    7. check with multimeter
  4. turn on main & secondary pumps (on the panel)
  5. monitor high vacuum ( Instrument control)
    • Scan Time: 1000000, Delay: 0.1 or 1?
    • 1e-6 → <1e-7 (after a whole weekend: 5e-8 for GasBench (2))
    • Source LED turns to green
  6. source
    1. check: turn on source with the needle valve closed
      • Emission & Voltage LED turns to green
      • HV, Box, Trap
      • Vac increases ~0.6e-8
    2. turn off source
    3. open needle valve (anti-clockwise one turn)
    4. turn on source
  7. tune
    1. Ref1 on
    2. Peak center, note down current sensitivity, screenshot current Focus Delta panel
    3. Auto focus
      • untick: Accelerating Voltage, Emission (max: 15 mA), Trap (max: 40 V), Electron Energy (max: 124 eV), Extraction Voltage (ca. 80%)
      • Measuring Channel: 1, Integration Time: 0.1 s, Min Step: 1, Max Step: 10, Min Delay: 50 ms, Max Delay: 500 ms, Max Iterations: 3, Simulated Poti Turn: 2
    4. save to: Global–Focus Settings–$DATE $NAME
    5. Pass to Gasconfiguration
  8. run CO2 OnOff *.seq (AS Method: Disabled, Method: CO2OnOff.met@GasBench (1), CARB ONOFF.met@GasBench (2)@Gasbench+acid, 100 measurements, save in $DATE CO2 ONOFF)
    • BGD44: 14 → 2.4 mV@GasBench (1), 10 → 2.8 → 2.4 mV@GasBench (2)
    • sensitivity: ↘︎↗︎↘︎—, tune again after stabilized
    • check linearity (1–10 V, step 1 V, δ13C: 0.04‰/V, δ18O: 0.05‰/V)

docs.title: De-ash
docs.text:
per ca. 200 samples

  1. Turn off source
  2. Turn off needle valve (turn knob clockwise ~360°, check: Vac xe-6 → xe-8)
  3. Check:
    • left T = 820 °C, right T = 450 °C
    • gas flow is off (switch on/off by F3)
  4. Deash
    1. unscrew, put the magazine on the right of the Cr tube to protect the plastic line
    2. take out metal insert (by a metal hook), cool down, deash later with a ⌀ 6.5mm drill
    3. check depth, replenish quartz wool, push in and check depth with the metal rod (having a black line mark)
    4. put another metal insert into the Cr tube
  5. Press F3: gas flow on, leak check
  6. Press F3: gas flow off
  7. ConFlo IV: Sample dilution max (98%)
  8. Turn on needle valve (counterclockwise, check: Vac xe-8 → xe-6)
  9. Turn on source
  10. Write down total (TOT) run number in log book

docs.title: Change chemicals
docs.text:
per >1000 samples, can be ~1300

  1. Prepare new
    • Cr tube (Elemental Microanalysis X1220) & Cu tube (Elemental Microanalysis X1222)
    • 2 black rubber O-rings (Elemental Microanalysis E1041)
    • 2 silicone/PTFE seals (Elemental Microanalysis E1021)
  2. Prepare new Cr tube & Cu tube
    1. Deash metal insert, put into Cr tube
    2. For better seal: take out extra quartz wool (Elemtex LECO® 502-177), push back so that no fibers stick out
    3. Put a black rubber O-ring on the top end (ref: packing diagrams in the manual)
  3. Take out 2 tubes (Cr tube, and then Cu tube)
    1. Turn off source
    2. Turn off needle valve (Check: Vac xe-6 → xe-8)
    3. Press F3: gas flow off
    4. Wear Kevlar gloves (prevent cut and heat)
    5. Disconnect bottom
      1. open closure
      2. move aside 2 metal holder (different height, so do not mix-up)
      3. unscrew alternately while holding metal tube
      4. put aside metal tube (do not mix-up)
      5. take off metal tube locking nut together with a metal O-ring and a black rubber O-ring
    6. Disconnect top
    7. Take out very hot tube (away from PFA tube)
  4. Install 2 tubes (Cr tube, and then Cu tube)
    1. Insert tube, connect top
    2. Connect bottom
    3. Press F3: gas flow on, leak check: all 4 connections, Press F3: gas flow off
  5. Change Mg(ClO4)2 tube for water trap
    • Open closure
    • Unscrew both ends, take off, clear
    • Insert quartz wool on one end, push it to the other end with an Allen key
    • Refill Mg(ClO4)2 (Acros Organics 413461000) with a funnel. Shake, but not too tight.
    • Insert quartz wool. Make sure no fibers stick out on both ends.
    • Install Mg(ClO4)2 tube with PTFE side of both seals facing upwards
    • Press F3: gas flow on, leak check (use paper to protect wires), Press F3: gas flow off
  6. Rest count: Init
  7. ConFlo IV: Sample dilution max (98%)
  8. Turn on needle valve (Check: Vac xe-8 → xe-6)
  9. Turn on source

docs.title: Procedures
docs.text:
1. Monday: reboot computer

    • icon on the taskbar: Shutdown (may be grey)
    • reboot computer
    • Kiel IV Carbonate: Turn on “Oven control” & check JUMO temperature controller light on the Front Panel

  2. Acid drop test

  3. LN2

    1. Take off blue LN2 dewar

    2. Check LN2 cylinder

      • 15 samples & 8 standards: consumes ~15%
      • 30 samples & 12 standards: consumes ~25%

    3. Moving

      • pressure inside vessel < 50% of the relief valve level
      • relief valve orientated away from face

    4. Change LN2 cylinder

      1. disconnect electric cable of the cryogenic solenoid valve (ASCO SCE263-205LT)
      2. disconnect Teflon hose (small nut)
        • !! hold the neighbouring male thread stud with a spanner to prevent from loosening or over-tightening
      3. disconnect cryogenic solenoid valve (big nut)
      4. connect: seal big nut with PTFE film, 3 times
      5. fully open outlet valve on LN2 cylinder, and then turn it back one full rotation

  4. Grease Kiel’s vials, insert disposable vials into Kiel’s vials

  5. Clear acid pump

    1. Acquisition – Kiel IV Carbonate: right Take magazine, until Ready...
    2. wipe off acid
    3. stick paper into the circular space around the needles to clean
    4. Monday: replace and grease O-ring (RS PRO, 129-072)
    5. check alignment of needle and sensor
    6. load empties/standards/samples
      • pos 1 for line 1, 2: empty vial
      • pos 2 for line 2: empty vial when using line 1 only sequence
    7. Kiel IV Carbonate: right Load magazine

  6. Check JUMO temperature controller

  7. Edit sequence in Acquisition (CO2_KielIV_Godwin_*.seq)

    1. input Identifier 1 for samples, Weight for standards
    2. Options: update date in the Folder Name and Export File Name
    3. Save
    4. Put on a dry blue LN2 dewar
    5. Start

  8. Method (CO2_KielIV_Godwin.met)

    • Refill Time: increase, when? how much?

docs.title: Replace bellow
docs.text:
1. Prepare
    1. bellow@10%
    2. source off
    3. all valves off
  2. remove valve body
    1. mark vales & compressed air lines
    2. disconnect round cable
    3. mark the position of anti-spin, and then remove anti-spin guide screw (2a)
    4. remove retaining screw (≈2c) from underneath
    5. remove travel adjustment set by removing 4 nuts
      • no need to remove brass cap
    6. remove spring pin (⌀ 3 mm, 4b)
      • have to set bellow@16% (so that spring pin is vertical)
    7. disconnect compressed air lines for 6 valves
    8. ref bellow:
      1. disconnect 2 metal lines at the top of valve body
      2. disconnect transducer
    9. remove 4 stud bolt nuts (+ 4 washers, 8 mm or 5/16”??)
      • !!! during reassemble: evenly screw in so that the new gold gasket is evenly compressed
    10. pull valve body off
  3. replace bellow
    1. remove 8 Allen key bolts
    2. push shaft from the other side (L wrench + hammer) + pull (4) stud bolts
      • burrs on shaft and/or bushing can make it difficult to pull or push it out. Gently file them off after removing the shaft
    3. screw out bushing (4a)
    4. move shaft to the new bellow
    5. move 4 stud bolts (unscrew 4 bolts on the brass retainer) to the new bellow
    6. install new gold gasket into recessed port
  4. clean and grease: bushing threads, shaft (optional)
  5. reassemble…
    • screw in bushing after putting shaft in place
  6. Tune
    1. pump and check leak (of valves, bellow, with Ar)
    2. bellow calibration
      1. Hardware Calibration
        • can manually set the position of the bushing (cf. position of the other bellow)
        • need to connect to the air (take off the metal blockage at the end of one metal line) to move the bellow
      2. Signal Calibration

docs.title: Monday to Thursday
docs.text:
1. Check & prepare
    1. Log on the screen: Finished Autorun
    2. Log paper
    3. Short press LF/FF button several times to feed paper forward until 4–5 holes are out
    4. Open & close ground-glass stopper of acid bottle
    5. Remove LN2 tubes from dewar
    6. Check 2 LN2 tube connections to cold fingers
    7. Put lids on samples
  2. Flush sample needle with He gas
    1. Prep–Move Gilson To Next Vial. If Gilson does not move: Prep–Initialise Gilson, then try again.
    2. AB, MH
    3. Check: AD
    4. AE
    5. Connect He gas, open cylinder valve, open regulator valve (<2 bar)
    6. Wipe off acid
    7. Check flow rate through the needle
    8. Disonnect He gas
  3. Pump out sample side
    1. Put on an old vial on needle: holes inside the vial & DO NOT touch the acid
    2. ML, AD, until ML vac ≈ 1.0e-3 (take out old sample vials in the heater block)
    3. Prep–Initialise Gilson
    4. Remove old vial
    5. AB, ML
    6. MH (auto ML)
  4. Refill reference gas
    1. Set reference gas bellow to 3100 (Stage 2)
    2. LV, RP, RV, until LV vac ≈ 1.0e-3 (Put new sample vials into the heater block)
    3. Inlet–Toggle C/O Valve, until 44 < 4e-11
    4. RM
    5. Check SP
    6. RI
    7. Manually operate 2 toggle valves (U: upper, L: lower) on reference gas cylinder
      1. L: pump out reference gas between the two valves 30s
      2. LV
      3. RP (Stage 2)
      4. L, U: release reference gas into the space between L and U 30s
      5. U, L: refill reference gas 30s (edit batch MPRPCM)
      6. L
    8. Measure reference gas
      1. RI, RP
      2. Set reference gas bellow to 0, until bellow fully open
      3. RM
      4. Check 44 ≈ 2.5e-9
  5. Edit batch MPRPCM
    1. Analysis–Autorun Batch Edit–select MPRPCM from the list
    2. MPRPCM: Setup
    3. Release all
    4. Enter new sample numbers, then OK–OK
  6. Reboot by Ctrl+Alt+Del
  7. Fill LN2 dewar
    • wear PPE
    • efficient transfer is achieved at 5–10 psi
    • filled to 90% of their net capacity to reduce the risk of spillage
    • 20L, record on the notebook
    • Check two tubes before putting them into the LN2 dewar: ~2 cm from the end of the wood stick
  8. Test–Peak Center, close scan
    • after Peak Center, check if Mass-44 is stable: fluctuate at the 4th decimal place
  9. Analysis–Autorun Start/Stop–select MPRPCM from the list, Run

docs.title: Friday Standby
docs.text:
1. Check status: Finished Autorun
  2. Remove LN2 tubes from dewar
  3. Prep–Water Trap Chiller Off
    • 2 LED lights off
  4. ML, AB (check: AC)
  5. LV, RP, RF, RV, RM, until LV vac ≈ 1.0e-3
    • optional: Set reference gas bellow to 3100 (Stage 2); RI, pump out, and then RI
  6. HV

docs.title: CO<sub>2</sub> from organic matter
docs.text:
1. Connect organic reference gas cylinder
    1. HV
    2. RP, RF, check RI
    3. Disconnect Carrara Z reference gas cylinder
    4. Connect organic reference gas cylinder
  2. Fill organic reference gas
    1. Set reference gas bellow to 1000
    2. Check SP
    3. LV, RP, RF, RV, RM until LV vac ≈ 1.0e-3
    4. Inlet–Toggle C/O Valve, until Mass-44 < 4e-11 A
    5. RM
    6. RI
    7. Manually operate 2 toggle valves (U: upper, L: lower) on organic reference gas cylinder
      1. L: pump out reference gas between two valves 30s
      2. L, U: release reference gas into the space between L and U 30s
      3. LV
      4. RP
      5. U, L: refill reference gas 30s
      6. L
  3. Check system status by measuring organic reference gas
    1. RI, RF (so that space between RF and SC can be used for sample gas later)
    2. RM
    3. Tune reference gas bellow (squeeze, larger value) ⟹ Mass-44 ≈ 6e-9
    4. Test–Peak Center, close scan
    5. RV
    6. Disable changeover ( Inlet-)
    7. Manually analyse against reference gas itself (DACP–CO2, Sample name: ORG GAS REF ZERO). Can do 4.
    8. !!! After run: Enable changeover
  4. Connect sample tube (during run for last sample/reference gas)
    1. Check RI
    2. Disconnect organic reference gas cylinder or last sample tube
    3. Cut glass sample tube, insert into metal tube (from the simple end)
    4. Connect (the more complicated end with a filter) to reference gas inlet
    5. LV, RI, RP, SP (space between RF and SF)
  5. Fill sample gas (after run for last sample/reference gas)
    1. Set sample gas bellow to 0
    2. LV, RI, RP, SP, SF, SV, SM (space between RF and SC) until LV vac ≈ 1.0e-3
    3. Inlet–Toggle C/O Valve, until Mass-44 < 4e-11 A
    4. LV
    5. Break sample tube, until Mass-44 is stable ( ?? 1 min)
  6. Measure sample gas
    1. RI, SF (store sample gas in between)
    2. Tune sample gas bellow (squeeze, larger value) ⟹ Mass-44 ≈ 6e-9, remember the value
    3. Inlet–Toggle C/O Valve, tune reference gas bellow (squeeze, larger value) ⟹ Mass-44 sample − reference ≈ 0.1 (?? 0.15)
    4. Inlet–Toggle C/O Valve, tune sample gas bellow (squeeze, larger value) ⟹ Mass-44 sample − reference ≈ 0.1 (?? 0.15)
    5. RV, SV
    6. Manually analyse (DACP–CO2, Sample name: …)
    7. Can do 4 when the analysis for current sample gas appears to be OK
  7. Repeat 4–6
  8. Standby
    1. (Check RI) Connect Carrara Z reference gas cylinder
    2. Changeover → waste
    3. Set both bellows to 0
    4. Pump all that is left of SI: LV, RI…, until LV vac ≈ 1.0e-3
    5. RI
    6. HV

docs.title: Misc.
docs.text:
• Scan config for OCR : 600 dpi, Gray scale, TIFF
  • Replenish reference gas:
    • Stage 1: RP, gradually decrease reference gas bellow (increase bellow size) through time
      • until 2024-01-23: 1400
    • Stage 2: RP, gradually decrease reference gas bellow (increase bellow size) through time

docs.title: Stop batch
docs.text:
1. Analysis–Autorun Start/Stop
  2. Program–Terminate
  3. Program–Run–STPFINGS, Run OR click 2 cold fingers respectively: Heat–Stop–Cool–Stop
    • Keep an eye on cold fingers, and run STPFINGS again if necessary
  4. Initialise Gilson
  5. batch MPRPCM: Release all
  6. reboot computer with GUI
  7. Initialise Gilson

docs.title: Power cut
docs.text:
1. Ion Gauge tripped:
    1. Mass Spec–Ion Gauge
    2. Power Selection: 1 mA (Ion Gauge 1, Filament 1), Set
  2. No signal (Mass-44: 2.98e-11)
    1. Mass Spec–Source ON
    2. Mass Spec–Tune Source
    3. Load: CO2 (Accelerating Voltage: 2602.7)
    4. Close
  3. Ref CO2 refill, Tests–Peak Center, RV, run Zero (>3 times)

docs.title: Solenoid valve can not be turned on/off
docs.text:
Symptoms:

  • Error: Too many small samples
  • Cannot pump out gas

Solution:

  1. Turn off pumps, test valves
  2. Change solenoid

Symptom: hear the leak

Solution: change (3) valve seals

docs.title: Phosphoric Acid (104%)
docs.text:
1. crystalline ortho-phosphoric acid (99%, ρ = 1.87, Sigma-Aldrich 1005650500) in water bath
  2. close valve, connect acid flask (round, otherwise implosion) to the glass manifolds
  3. ‘U’ & spiral water traps (LN2 in blue dewars) & 1 contamination (e.g., oil from vacuum pump) trap (LN2 in black bucket)
  4. open valve (vacuum)
  5. stirring (200 RPM) & boiling water bath (250 °C) for 6 h ⟹ 104%, ρ = 1.93
    • use a safety screen
    • replenish water & LN2 every 30 mins
  6. finish
    1. stop heating, lower water bath, cool off
    2. wipe off water around the connection, release vacuum, disconnect
    3. next day: disconnect and dry glass condensate traps

References: Burman 2005

docs.title: Phosphoric Acid (>104%)
docs.text:
polyphosphoric acid 115% (Sigma-Aldrich 208213) + water

docs.title: Set up
docs.text:
1. fill dewar on pump trap with LN2
  2. put carbonate and stirrer bar in reaction vessel
  3. top up acid reservoir with orthophosphoric acid (104%)
  4. fill dewars on ‘U’ & spiral water traps with ethanol (−80 °C)
  5. heat water bath to 90 °C (to avoid temperature fractionation of oxygen)
  6. connect ref gas cylinder to line and pump
  7. pump whole line down to 1e-3 mbar

docs.title: Manufacture
docs.text:
1. close ref gas valve
  2. close valve to pump, check for leaks
  3. fill dewar on ‘U’ CO2 trap with LN2
  4. slowly drop acid and turn on stirrer
  5. vac gauge will rise the fall as produced CO2 is frozen down
  6. steadily add more acid
  7. reaction takes 45 mins to 1 hour
  8. close off valve to reaction vessel (open vessel vent)
  9. vacuum should drop back to 1e-3 (ideally!)

  10. pump over frozen CO2 to remove any uncondensables

  11. isolate line from pump and send CO2 back over the water traps

  12. put LN2 dewar on ‘carrot’ CO2 trap
  13. remove LN2 from ‘U’ CO2 trap, CO2 will refreeze on ‘carrot’ CO2 trap
  14. vacuum should drop back to 1e-3 (ideally!)

  15. pump over frozen CO2 to remove any uncondensables

  16. isolate line from pump and send CO2 back over the water traps

  17. put LN2 dewar on ‘U’ CO2 trap
  18. remove LN2 from ‘carrot’ CO2 trap, CO2 will refreeze on ‘U’ CO2 trap
  19. vacuum should drop back to 1e-3
  20. pump over frozen CO2 to remove any uncondensables
  21. isolate water traps form frozen CO2 trap
  22. open ref gas cylinder valve
  23. isolate line from vac pump
  24. fill ref gas dewar with LN2
  25. remove LN2 from ‘U’ CO2 trap
  26. freeze ref gas into cylinder
  27. vacuum should drop back to 1e-3
  28. pump over frozen CO2 to remove any uncondensables
  29. close ref gas cylinder, remove from line and allow to warm up.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
expansion volume and second carrot trap is for ‘emergency’. It is a pre-evacuated 5 L volume that CO2 can be allowed to expand into in case of any problems.

100 g CaCO3 = 22.4 L CO2 gas @ room temp (1 atm)

docs.title: Sieving
docs.text:
Sieving Expedition 397 U1385 samples. Work in stratigraphic sequence.

  1. Disaggregation
    1. Take samples from a big plastic bag and sort them into cardboard boxes
    2. Take out samples according to labels prepared by Simon, put other samples into 2 mid-size plastic bags and then put back into the original big plastic bag
    3. Label (A, plastic, small) wide neck 250 ml conical flask
      • Put Label (A) on white electrical tape, and then put white electrical tape onto flask, so that Label (A, together with electrical tape) can be easily detached later
    4. Place flask onto the scale, tare
    5. Break samples into >3 parts and put into flask, weight of bulk sample
      • Keep a small piece of spare sample in the original plastic bag and seal with a heat sealer
    6. Add ~100 ml de-ionised (DI) water (almost, but do not fully submerge sample)
    7. Put on orange rubber bung
      • Simon & Jeannie: marked with a blue dot
      • DO NOT push down
    8. Put onto orbital shaker set at close to 200 rotations
      1. After 10 minutes, check subsamples are moving (detached from base) in beaker. If a lump is “stuck”, usually in the middle, try to move it to the side. Adjust speed as needed — different samples have different lowest working speeds.
      2. Leave for <4–5 hours. Shorter period is preferable, as long as samples reach a soupy slurry state. Higher rotations or longer period may crush or damage tests, esp. when there are big pyrites.
  2. Sieve
    1. Label (B, paper, big) plastic resealable bag
    2. write weight of resealable bag onto itself
      • Put a tape roll as a holder onto the balance
    3. Open resealable bag and put into 1000 mL (reusable) beaker
    4. Move Label (A) on flask to sieve
    5. Put 150 µm mesh ⌀100 mm stainless steel sieve on top of beaker
    6. Washout soupy slurry in flask with DI water, use higher flow rate (loosen spray nozzle)
    7. Sieve with DI water, use lower flow rate, i.e., fine aerosol (tighten spray nozzle)
      • may need one additional 1000 ml CLEAN beaker for fine fraction when there are big lumps
    8. Put flasks onto trolley for later wash by glassware washer
  3. Coarse fraction (foraminifera) on sieve:
    1. Put into oven at 40 °C, >1 hour until completely dry
    2. Take off Label (A) on sieve, trim it with a scissor, and then put it onto glass vial as a backup
    3. Label (C, plastic, small) glass vial
    4. Clean up triangle cardboard holder & metal funnel with brush
    5. Put triangle cardboard holder on to the scale
    6. Transfer coarse fraction from sieve to cardboard holder with two hard brushes (one made from tooth brush, mainly brush underneath the sieve; another No. 10 flat brush, brush inside the sieve and for transfer). dry weight
    7. Transfer into glass vial with a metal funnel and a soft round No.4 brush
    8. Write sample info on the cap of glass vial
  4. Fine fraction (coccoliths, nannofossils, etc.) in resealable bag (in beaker):
    1. Settle, 3 or 4 days until liquid is clear
    2. Drain by pump as much as possible, without disturbing fine particles
    3. Optional: transfer the portion from the additional beaker to the resealable bag (rinse and transfer), settle–drain
    4. Dry in 50 °C oven
    5. Sort on a desk
    6. dry weight and weight of resealable bag
      • Put a tape roll as a holder onto the balance
    7. Put into a big bag
      • Gather samples from the same section into one big plastic resealable bag
    8. Google spreadsheet: SedLab Copy of U1385 CSF-A and CCSF depths for BCR samples

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Samples are prepared in order, starting from the top of a core and working downwards. This minimises any errors with labelling through out the whole process.
  • In some cases sieve may need to be sonicated a few seconds to remove the coarse fraction trapped in the mesh.
  • Contents of water and coarse fraction can be calculated from recorded weights.
